description.narrative: Enhancing Resilience of Agriculture landscape and value chains in Uganda with outputs 1,2 and 3(CSA technologies and practices, CSA approaches are promoted, and organizational arrangements and capacities are strengthened.

participating-org.narrative: Common Market for Eastern and Southern Africa (COMESA)

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

provider-org.narrative: Common Market for Eastern and Southern Africa (COMESA)
Common Market for Eastern and Southern Africa (COMESA)
Common Market for Eastern and Southern Africa (COMESA)

Common Market for Eastern and Southern Africa (COMESA)

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).

description.narrative: 1.1 number of cooperative members / farmers integrating CSA practices and using sustainable production technologies 1.2 number of hectares under conservation agriculture practices 1.3 km of soil and water conservation bands constructed 1.4 existence of a functional M&E framework (with regular generation, dissemination and use of update data; disaggregated by gender, location, etc where applicable) that has integrated value chain approach indicators 2.1 number of active school CSA clubs; and number of schools integrating CSA practices into their curricular & co-curricular activities mainly school gardening 2.2 Ha of school gardens integrating CSA practices and technologies. 3.1 number of functional platforms established/strengthen that engage stakeholders / enterprises value chain actors for the implementation of CSA, including, mainstream gender responsive actions/practices. 3.2 existence of a strategy, that is gender inclusive, for access of CSA technology inputs & services 3.3 number of districts that have functional CSA taskforces actively coordinating, monitoring and facilitating partnerships building for the implementation of CSA activities number of functional farmer cooperative enterprises in place 3.4 existence of a functional M&E framework (with regular generation, dissemination and use of update data; disaggregated by gender, location, etc where applicable) that has integrated value chain approach indicators.

comment.narrative: 1.1: 2 groups 1.2 : 3000 Ha 1.3: 12 Km 1.4: CSA M&E system in place but not functional 2.1: 0 2.2: 0 3.1: - no functional platforms 3.2:- no strategy 3.3: 0 3.4: CSA M&E system in place but not functional

Output 1. By 2021, CSA practices are up scaled and monitored in seven districts in eastern Uganda 1.2 Build capacity of 15 cooperatives to access revolving fund and matching grants and distribute revolving funds 1.3 Build capacity of 15cooperatives to access and use draught and tractor driven rippers 1.4 Support farmer field days for cross learning
1.5 Establish 30 micro irrigation units and conduct trainings on irrigation practices 1.6 promote production of Neem tree seedlings and use of Neem seed pesticides. Output 2. By 2021, CSA approaches are promoted in selected schools in the seven districts in Eastern Uganda 2.1 Develop CSA manual to guide teachers and pupils 2.2 Support the set up of school gardens & practical skilling of pupils and teachers in CSA technologies, practices and approaches in the selected schools 2.3 Support development of school clubs
Output 3. By 2021, the organizational arrangements and capacities are strengthened for implementation of CSA and management of strategic value chains. 3.1 Support the functioning of CSA taskforce for better coordination and monitoring of CSA activities 3.3Facilitate growth of 3 value chains for growth of partnerships and development of action plans. 3.4 Provide matching grants to promote investments by farmer cooperatives in CSA mechanization practices, produce bulking, post-harvest handling and value addition

1.2 Capacity of 15 cooperatives built to access revolving funds and matching grants but distribution of the grants not yet done. 1.3 Capacity of 15cooperatives to access and use draught driven rippers was done but not for tractor driven rippers 1.4 Farmer Field days for cross learning were not done because of COVID restrictions 1.5 Establishment of micro-irrigation units is at procurement stage with specifications developed 1.6 Production of Neem tree seedlings is on-going although was delayed by seed collection season and use of Neem seed pesticides has not yet taken off 2.1 Development of CSA Manual to guide teachers and pupils is at procurement of consultant. 2.2 Setting of school gardens and practical skilling of pupils and teachers was not done because of interaction of COVID-19

Output 1. By 2021, CSA practices are up scaled and monitored in seven districts in eastern Uganda 1.2 Build capacity of 15 cooperatives to access revolving fund and matching grants and distribute revolving funds
1.2.4 Disburse revolving fund grants to 15 cooperatives to procure quality inputs for savers to access on favourable loan conditions 1.2.5 Capacity Building and monitoring performance of cooperatives and revolving fund utilization 1.2.6 Procure visibility materials for cooperatives and the project (T-shirts, brochures, posters, harddisks) 1.4.1 Support 7 farmer open days to share and learn about good CSA practices 1.5.3 Establish at least 30 demonstration of micro irrigation units and capacity building for the users) 1.6.1. Demonstrate use of neem tree bio-pesticide among the 15 cooperatives 1.6.2 Support production of neem tree seedlings for farmer planting (7 nurseries : seeds, inputs, materials, equipment and tools) 1.8.1 Local Consultant to document and evaluate CSA best practices 1.8.5 Project quarterly review meeting, bi-annual board meetings
Output 2. By 2021, CSA approaches are promoted in selected schools in the seven districts in Eastern Uganda 2.1.1 Develop an illustrative manual (handbook) and communication strategy on CSA practices 2.1.2 Establish and Monitor CSA demonstration gardens in 14 schools.
2.2.2 Support school club activities (awareness and learning) 2.3.1 Support monitoring mission by MoE and District Education officers to assess integration of CSA practices in schools extra curricular activities
3.1 Functional platforms established/strengthened to engage stakeholders / enterprises value chain actors for the implementation of CSA, including, mainstream gender responsive actions/practices. 3.1.1 Support the functioning of National CSA taskforce to guide project on value chains developments, and for better coordination and monitoring of CSA activities 3.1.2 Support the functioning of District CSA taskforce to guide project on value chains developments, and for better coordination and monitoring of CSA activities 3.2 A gender inclusive strategy for access of CSA technology inputs & services established 3.2.1 Facilitate a team of district and national level taskforces to analyze and develop gender responsive actions to strengthen stakeholder engagements across the strategic value chains (pulses, cereals, fruits, neem tree products) 3.2.2 Facilitate three sub-regional level platforms (grain, fruit, and neem enterprises) for value chain actors to form, develop action plans, and exhibit CSA agro inputs, products, technologies, and services for CSA cooperatives to establish partnership contracts 3.2.3 Capacity Building & Monitoring Mission Support to 15 interns to support cooperatives on ICT and compile data/information to present at platform meetings 3.3.1 Facilitate cross learning visits by the 15 cooperatives focusing on organised marketing, savings and credit management, good documentation practices and performing cottage processing and value addition industries of similar enterprises 3.3.2 Support extension (coordination, supervision, backstopping and monitoring) by PMU and partners to CSA activities in cooperatives and schools 3.3.3 Facilitate hands on trainings in post-harvesting, processing, value addition, value addition, and processing hygiene and sanitation 3.4.1 Provide matching grants to meet investing requirements of the 15 cooperatives 3.4.2 Facilitate investment in post harvest handling equipment for grain / pulse and neem product processing 4.0 Terminal Evaluation conducted

1.2.4 Revolving fund grants worth USD 64,492 were disbursed to 15 cooperatives and inputs were procured by each cooperative. 1.2.5 Capacity of cooperatives to utilize revolving funds was built and performance was monitored 1.2.6 Visibility materials including T-shirts, umbrellas and bags were procured and distributed to cooperatives 1.4.1 Farmer open days were not carried out because of COVID-19 restrictions on congregation 1.5.3 Thirty (30) micro-irrigation demonstration sites established and users trained 1.6.1 Demonstration of the use of neem-tree biopesticides to 15cooperatives was done 1.6.2 Seven (7) tree nurseries established and production of neem tree seedlings supported . Up to 7000 tree seedlings produced and planted on farm boundaries 1.8.1 CSA best practices documented 1.8.5 One quarterly review and 1 board meeting held during the year 2.1.1 An illustrative manual and communication strategy on CSA developed 2.1.2 Demonstration gardens were NOT established in the 14 schools but schools were supported to procure equipment to use in establishing the school gardens 2.2.2 School clubs activities were supported to procure awareness materials to be used when the schools open 2.3.1 Monitoring visit by MoE was NOT carried out as schools remained closed 3.1.1 National CSA taskforce activities on value chains developments, and for better coordination and monitoring of CSA activities supported 3.1.2 District CSA taskforce activities on value chains developments, and for better coordination and monitoring of CSA activities supported 3.2.2 Sub-regional level platforms for grain, fruit, and neem enterprises for value chain actors facilitated with capacity building 3.2.3 Capacity of 15 interns built to support the cooperatives. 3.4.1 Matching grants worth USD 85,365 provided to cooperatives and used for acquisition of value addition equipment 3.4.2 Investments in postharvest handling facilities worth USD 18,743 and several physical equipment 4.0 Terminal Evaluation of the project conducted

Output 1. By 2021, CSA practices are up scaled and monitored in seven districts in eastern Uganda 1.1 Conduct capacity building workshops for 60 cooperatives ToTs to lead & facilitate farmers in CSA activities 1.5 Establish 3 micro irrigation units and conduct trainings on irrigation practices 1.7 Undertake a baseline study to establish CSA indicator levels and prepare M&E guidelines to facilitate multi-stakeholder participatory Output 2. By 2021, CSA approaches are promoted in selected schools in the seven districts in Eastern Uganda 2.1 Support the set up of school gardens & practical skilling of pupils and teachers in CSA technologies, practices and approaches in the selected schools 2.2 Support awareness campaigns on climate smart agriculture
Output 3. By 2021, the organizational arrangements and capacities are strengthened for implementation of CSA and management of strategic value chains. 3.1 Support the functioning of CSA taskforce for better coordination and monitoring of CSA activities 3.3 Conduct trainings & cross learning visits to strengthen organizational, marketing, financial & knowledge management capacities of farmer cooperatives 3.4 Promote investments by farmer cooperatives in CSA mechanization practices, produce bulking, post-harvest handling and value addition

Output1 Capacity building workshops were held for 60 trainers within cooperatives and for 20technical persons in DLGs to enhance skills on CSA practices and technologies Micro irrigation units and trainings on irrigation practices were not done to allow feasibility studies on the sites to be completed Baseline studies to establish CSA indicator levels were done M&E guidelines to facilitate multi-stakeholder participation was developed
Output2 Awareness campaigns in schools were done for 14 schools and capacity building was done for 52science teachers (22women) on CSA practices and technologies. School gardens were not set yet but land was allocated for the set up and garden plans were done by each school. a bill of quantities for the requirements of each school garden was also established.
Output 3 CSA task forces were set up at district and national levels and members were initiated to their roles and responsibilities in enhancing adoption of CSA practices
Coordination of cooperatives activities was done by equipping them with computers, furniture and bicycles to facilitate management of their centres One cross learning visit was conducted for 45members of cooperatives (12women), building their capacities on organizational, marketing and financial management of farmer cooperatives Investments by farmer cooperatives did not take off in mechanization and produce bulking yet
